poem:
Island of Strangers

In the fabric of an island,  
threads of belonging unravel—  
past war's shadow,  
a father's silent honor flickers  
beneath starless skies.  
Stranger on a familiar shore,  
home shifts in speech.  
Lines drawn,  
distance unspoken  
in a place  
once thought  
whole.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Branded a stranger by Labour on an island I call home | Letter Jenni Daiches writes about her sense of alienation from the Labour party after Keir Starmer’s “island of strangers” speech (Letters, 22 May). My father fought with the British Indian army in Burma and Singapore as a young officer during the second world war. He even got a mention in the king’s dispatches. He elected to stay in the Pakistan army after partition". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
